35 year old female presents with acute right flank pain, dysuria, and fever

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Acute Pyelonephritis
Disease Discussion

Acute pyelonephritis is an infection of the upper urinary tract that usually occurs when colonic bacterial ascend from the lower urinary tract to invade the renal parenchyma. E. coli is the most frequent organism, with Proteus, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus saprophyticus, and Enterococcus being less common. The role of imaging is generally to define underlying pathology (obstruction, reflux, calculus) and rule out complications (abscess, emphysematous pyelonephritis, changes consistent with chronic infection). IVP, CT, US, can be normal in up to 75% of cases. CT findings (when present) include: renal enlargement (edema); areas of decreased perfusion/enhancement; stranding of the perirenal fat; striated nephrogram with contrast enhanced studies. A striated nephrogram appears as alternating linear lucency/density parallel to tubules & collecting ducts due to stasis of contrast material in dilated ducts on a background of edematous renal parenchyma. This finding can also be seen with IVP, and is non-specific. The pneumonic CHOIR BOY can be used to remember the differential diagnosis for a striated nephroghrm: Contusion; Hypotension; Obstruction (ureteral); Intratubular obstruction; Renal vein thrombosis; Obstruction (ureteral—because it’s so common); Yes, also cystic diseases (infantile PCKD, medullary cystic disease, medullary sponge kidney).
ACR Code

8.2
Location

Genitourinary
Category

Infection, bacteria
Keywords

striated nephrogram


Reference

Saunders Manual of Medical Practice. Primer of Diagnostic Imagaing, 3rd ed. Radiology Review Manual, 5th ed.
( This topic was added on 2003-09-15 and last edited on 2006-10-29 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Intracranial Epidermoid Cyst (Retroclival)
History

63 y.o. man presents with a two week history of headache and facial numbness.
Exam

Evidence of trigeminal and facial nerve dysfunction.
Findings

Multiplanar and multisequence MR Imaging demonstrates the presence of an intradural multilobulated lesion located in the prepontine and interpeduncular cistern. The lesion is isointense on T1-weighted sequence and on T2-weighted sequence and hyperintense on FLAIR sequence compared to CSF signal intensity. The lesion is hyperintense on diffusion-weighted images (b-value:1000 sec/mm2). On apparent diffusion coeffficient (ADC) maps the lesion is hypointense to CSF, suggesting restricted diffusion within the substance of the lesion. The findings are consistent with epidermoid cyst.
Differential Diagnosis

Differential diagnosis includes: arachnoid cyst, dermoid cyst, neurocysticercosis, cystic neoplasm.
Case Diagnosis

Intracranial epidermoid cyst (retroclival)
Diagnosis By

Typical MR Imaging findings
Treatment & Follow Up

The patient is referred for Neurosurgery consultation.
Discussion

The incomplete nulling of the lesion on FLAIR sequence and the restricted diffusion on DWI supported the diagnosis of epidermoid cyst , ruling out arachnoid cyst Post contrast T1 weighted images were not obtained for unknown reasons. We would expect minimal enhancement of the lesion on post contrast images. High-resolution steady-state free precession (SSFP) images would delineate better the relationship of the epidermoid cyst with the cranial nerves of the prepontine and interpeduncular cisterns
( This case was added on 2014-06-30 and last edited on 2014-07-01 )

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Intracranial Epidermoid Inclusion Cyst
Disease Discussion

Intracranial epidermoid cyst is a congenital inclusion cyst which arises from ectodermal inclusions during neural tube closure , third to fifth week of embryogenesis. It is the most common intracranial congenital lesion. Epidermoid tumors are slow-growing, benign lesions. They have an equal incidence in men and women, typically occur between the ages of 20 and 60, and have a peak incidence in the fourth decade. Macroscopically, it is characterized by lobulated excrescences and shiny appearance. It has a insinuating growth pattern and tends to encase surrounding structures. Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of stratified cuboidal squamous epithelium with cilia. They are filled with cholesterol crystals and keratinaceous debris. Symptoms vary depending on the location and the growth pattern of the epidermoid cyst. The most common symptoms are headache and cranial nerve palsies (V,VII,VIII). Epidermoid cyst may remain clinically silent for many years. CT findings of epidermoid cyst include a hypodense cyst which may contain calcifications and shows faint enhancement following contrast administration. MR Imaging features of epidermoid cyst are that of a slightly hyperintense to CSF cystic lesion on T1 weighted images and isointense to slight hyperintense to CSF on T2 weighted images. On FLAIR images , epidermoid cyst is not completely nulled. Following gadolinium administration, epidermoid cysts exhibit minimal enhancement. A characteristic feature of epidermoid cysts is the restricted diffusion on Diffusion Weighted Images and Apparent Diffusion Coefficient maps with reported epidermoid ADC values lower than CSF ADC and approximating brain ADC. Treatment includes microsurgical resection. There is increased risk of complications due to encasement of the surrounding structures.
ACR Code

1.3
Location

Brain and Neuro
Category

Cyst, benign
Keywords

arachnoid cyst ependymal cyst dermoid cyst
congenital cyst

Reference

1. Pei-yi Gao, 1 Anne G. Osborn, James G. Smirniotopoulos, and Cheryl P. Harris Epidermoid Tumor of the Cerebellopontine Angle Radiologic-Pathologic Correlation AJNR 13:863-872, May/ June 1992 2.Diagnostic Imaging Brain 2nd Edition Anne Osborn 3. Bergui et al Diffusion-weighted images of intracranial cyst-like lesions. Neuroradiology 2001 43: 824-829. 4. David Kallmes et al: Typical and atypical MR Imaging features of intracranial epidermoid tumors. AJR:169, September 1997
( This topic was added on 2014-06-30 and last edited on 2014-07-01 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Asthma With Air Trapping
History

Wheezing, no fever
Exam

Diffuse expiratory wheezing
Findings

Hyperinflated lungs with flattening of hemidiaphragms and increased AP diameter
Differential Diagnosis

• Reactive airway disease (asthma)
• Viral illness with diffuse air trapping
Case Diagnosis

Asthma with air trapping
Diagnosis By

Clinical presentation, known asthma attack that improved with bronchodilators
Treatment & Follow Up

• bronchodilators
• steroids
Discussion

• Reactive airway disease and viral illness can have similar features to include bronchial wall thickening (cuffing and tram-tracks), hyperinflation from air trapping (partial bronchial obstruction), and atelectasis (areas of complete bronchial obstruction; ie: mucous plugging)
• Airblock phenomena are more likely in asthmatic patients, to include pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax

case_details_text:
CASE
Nonaccidental Trauma
History

2 year old previously healthy boy brought to ED by mother and her boyfriend. Chief complaints on admission were: vomiting 3-4 times for 5 days, decreased PO intake, decreased activity, problems walking. Mother reports that her son is weak in left arm and left leg, and he falls a lot. She thought it was side effect from Motrin she was giving to the child.
Exam

General: Patient is lethargic, spontaneously opens his eyes, withdraws in response to pain, incomprehensible sounds heard from him occasionally. Vitals: HR=100, R=30, BP=163/76, T=99F, W=15kg (75%), Ht=92(75%) Skin: pale, multiple old and new bruises, lacerations, scars. 1/2in. laceration with hematoma on right side of forehead, 1/4 in. laceration of right upper side of the cheek, small bruise on right side of mandible, bruise on left cheek, small bruise of right upper abdominal quadrant, small bruise on right inner thigh, two 1/4in. bruises on perineum, small healed scar on left knee, right posterior calf, left forearm - all are under 1/2 inch. HEENT/Neuro: Deviation of the eyes to the right, pupils 3mm, sluggish. Several bruises, lacerations are noted on face (see Skin) Decreased muscle tone and absent movement of left upper and lower extremities. Chest: symmetric, no retractions, clear to auscultation bilaterally. CV: normal S1 and S2, regular rhythm and rate, no murmur Abdomen: mildly distended, soft, no hepato-splenomegaly, decreased bowel sounds. Genitalia: Tanner 1, male, testes are in the scrotum Extremities: warm, well perfused, no clubbing, cyanosis, edema. WBC-14.2 Hb-8.5 Htc-27.7 Plt-489
Findings

Initial head CT demonstrates hyperdense subdural hemorrhage along the right convexity and effacement of sulci and loss of gray-white differentiation of the right cerebrum indicative of diffuse edema. MR shows subdural blood with signal characteristics of extracellular methemoglobin anterior to both frontal lobes and along the tentorium cerebelli on the right. There is restricted diffusion in the right cerebrum due to acute infarction. Frontal radiograph of the ribs shows bilateral lateral acute fractures of the lower ribs, also seen on CT images through the lower chest/upper abdomen. The later CT image shows callus formation in the anterolater lateral ribs bilaterally. The CT through the kidneys shows delayed tubular transit time and excretion on the left which could be due to trauma.
Differential Diagnosis

0. Accidental head trauma 1. Non-Accidental head trauma 2. Cerebral Infarction 3. Coagulopathy with intracranial hemorrhage 4. Arterial-venous malformation 5. Meningitis/Encephalitis 6. Seizure disorder 7. Medication toxicity 8. Osteogenesis imperfecta 9. Other rare conditions: Menkes syndrome, osteopetrosis, scurvy, hypophosphotasia, congenital syphilitic periostitis, leukemia, vitamin A toxicity, and metabolic and kidney diseases that cause calcium wasting and demineralization
Case Diagnosis

Nonaccidental trauma
Diagnosis By

History inconsistent with injuries
Treatment & Follow Up

1. Mannitol, 3% saline to decrease brain edema 2. Phenytoin for seizures control 3. PRBC transfusion for Anemia treatment 4. Hydralasine/ Captopril/ Enalapril for blood pressure management 5. Total Parenteral Nutrition, NGCD later on 6. Physical therapy 7. Speech therapy 8. Rehabilitation facility
Discussion

This baby developed irreversable left hemiparesis and left hemianopsia. The alleged perpetrator has fled the country.
( This case was last edited on 2013-09-13 )

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Shaken Baby Syndrome
Disease Discussion

An estimated 2,815,600 children are harmed or endangered by their caretakers annually. About 1,400 children die annually in the United States from inflicted injury and the number of fatally injured children seems to be increasing. Boys, twins and stepchildren are particularly at risk. Infants are more vulnerable to fatal head trauma, whereas toddlers are more vulnerable to fatal abdominal trauma. Shaken baby syndrome is a serious form of child maltreatment most often involving children younger than 2 years. It results from extreme rotational cranial acceleration induced by violent shaking or shaking/impact, which would be easily recognizable by others as dangerous. The association of head injuries and fractures was reported by the pediatric radiologist, John Caffey in 1946. In 1971, Guthkelch, first postulated the mechanism of shaking as the cause of the brain injury and the constellation of findings in abused infants, which included retinal hemorrhages, subdural and/or subarachnoid hemorrhages, and little or no evidence of external cranial trauma. History: The child may present to ED accompanied by a caregiver with injuries the practitioner subsequently determines to be abusive. A careful history should be obtained as to how the injury or assault occurred. Historical characteristics of child maltreatment: -Poorly explained injuries -Changing history -Injuries incompatible with stated history -Delay in seeking treatment Caretakers may have: - Unrealistic expectations from a child - Tension and frustration from child’s crying and irritability - Stress from environmental, social, biological or financial situations - History of domestic violence and/or substance abuse Nonspecific symptoms of head injuries: -Lethargy -Unexplained vomiting -Convulsions -Apnea -Coma Symptoms of abdominal trauma -Pain -Vomiting -Shock -Sepsis Physical: The physical examination offers an opportunity to assess the child for the classic injuries of physical abuse and to assess the child’s general well being. Findinds of Shaken Baby Syndrome include: - Retinal hemorrhages - Intracranial hemorrhages, particularly subdural hemorrhage - Diffuse axonal injury - Secondary cerebral edema - Fractures of the posterior and anterolateral ribs and/or metaphyses of long bones Findings that are characteristic of abuse: - Injuries in various stages of healing - Multiplanar injuries (back and front together, right and left side together) - Injuries with obvious pattern (hand or implement) - Assault like locations of injuries (trunk, upper arms, upper legs, neck, face, perineal area) - Bruises on nonambulating infant Retinal and vitreous hemorrhages and nonhemorrhagic changes, including retinal folds and traumatic retinoschisis, are characteristic of shaken baby syndrome. They are usually found in 75% to 90 % of cases. The number, character, location, and size of retinal hemorrhages after shaking injury vary from case to case. More severe retinal hemorrhages are associated with more brain injury. The shaken infant is often mildly to moderately anemic. Coagulation studies may show moderate changes, rarely severe (eg, disseminated intravascular coagulation). Elevated transaminase levels may indicate liver injury, high amylase levels may signify pancreatic damage, presence blood in urine suggests renal trauma. Lab studies: 1. CBC (mild to moderate anemia, due to malnourishment and/or hemorrhage) 2. Coagulation profile (to rule out coagulopathy) 3. UA ( hematuria indicates kidney or urethral trauma, occult blood indicates rhabdomyolysis) 4. Stool guaiac (occult abdominal trauma) 5. Transaminases, amylase (abdominal trauma) Imaging: 1. Photographs of all injuries 2. Noncontrast head CT 3. MRI of the brain if there is persistent suspcion of abuse or abnormality on the CT 3. Full skeletal survey for nonaccidental trauma 4. CT scan of the abdomen if blunt trauma suspected in older child 5. Chest CT 6. Repeat skeletal survey or radionucleotide bone scan to increase detection of particularly rib fractures Treatment: 1. Airway, breathing, circulatory resuscitation and medication administration 2. Hospitalization 3. Reabilitation Child protective services and law enforcement notification =================================================== Additional References National Center on Shaken Baby Syndrome:
http://www.dontshake.com/ Arch Dis Childhood:
http://adc.bmjjournals.com/cgi/content/full/86/2/98 American Academy of Pediatrics:
http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/pediatrics;105/6/1345

View Topic Images
topic
Shaken Baby Syndrome
Disease Discussion
An estimated 2,815,600 children are harmed or endangered by their caretakers annually. About 1,400 children die annually in the United States from inflicted injury and the number of fatally injured children seems to be increasing. Boys, twins and stepchildren are particularly at risk. Infants are more vulnerable to fatal head trauma, whereas toddlers are more vulnerable to fatal abdominal trauma. Shaken baby syndrome is a serious form of child maltreatment most often involving children younger than 2 years. It results from extreme rotational cranial acceleration induced by violent shaking or shaking/impact, which would be easily recognizable by others as dangerous. The association of head injuries and fractures was reported by the pediatric radiologist, John Caffey in 1946. In 1971, Guthkelch, first postulated the mechanism of shaking as the cause of the brain injury and the constellation of findings in abused infants, which included retinal hemorrhages, subdural and/or subarachnoid hemorrhages, and little or no evidence of external cranial trauma. History: The child may present to ED accompanied by a caregiver with injuries the practitioner subsequently determines to be abusive. A careful history should be obtained as to how the injury or assault occurred. Historical characteristics of child maltreatment: -Poorly explained injuries -Changing history -Injuries incompatible with stated history -Delay in seeking treatment Caretakers may have: - Unrealistic expectations from a child - Tension and frustration from child’s crying and irritability - Stress from environmental, social, biological or financial situations - History of domestic violence and/or substance abuse Nonspecific symptoms of head injuries: -Lethargy -Unexplained vomiting -Convulsions -Apnea -Coma Symptoms of abdominal trauma -Pain -Vomiting -Shock -Sepsis Physical: The physical examination offers an opportunity to assess the child for the classic injuries of physical abuse and to assess the child’s general well being. case_details_text:
CASE
Acute Cholecystitis With Gall Stones (Calculus Cholecystitis)
History

57 year old Nondiabetic female with a 2 day history of vague abdominal pain.
Exam

Abdomen: Tender to palpation with no peritoneal signs. Negative Murphy’s sign. AMYLASE . . . . . . . <30 (28-110) U/L LIPASE. . . . . . . . . 53 (23-300) U/L WBC . . . . . . . . . . 15.7 H(4.0-11.0) K/UL HGB . . . . . . . . . . 13.4 (12.0-16.0) g/dL HCT . . . . . . . . . . 39.7 (37-47) % PLT CNT . . . . . . . 223 (150-450) K/UL
Findings

CR: Supine radiograph of the abdomen demonstrates a non-obstructive gas pattern with multiple calcified stones in the right upper quadrant. Erect view of the abdomen demonstrates calcifications overlying the right L5/S1 level, suggesting elongation of the gallbladder and concerning for significant distention. There is a focal calcification suspicious for being located in the gallbladder neck. CT: Contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen demonstrates elongation of the gallbladder (14 cm), gallbladder wall thickening, Pericholecystic inflammation, cholelithiasis, and a stone in the gallbladder neck.
Differential Diagnosis

Acute calculus cholecystitis Cholangitis
Case Diagnosis

Acute cholecystitis with Gall Stones (Calculus cholecystitis)
Diagnosis By

Surgery
Treatment & Follow Up

Cholecystectomy
Discussion

The patient had nonspecific symptoms of abdominal pain which was not localizable which confounded the clinician. Considering the plain radiographic findings of elongation of the bladder and a suspicious calcification in the gallbladder neck, cholecystitis was high on the differential. CT findings were strongly suspicious for acute calculus cholecystitis. Subsequent surgery was confirmatory which demonstrated a diffusely hemorrhagic surface to the gallbladder with thick yellow purulent exudate adherent to the surface. The CT findings were both sensitive and specific for acute calculus cholecystitis.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
CT Evaluation Of Acute Cholecystitis
Disease Discussion

Acute cholecystitis is a result of obstruction of the cystic duct. Consequently there is inflammation of the gallbladder wall. The vast majority is due to impacted gallstones. Sonography or hepatobiliary scintigraphy are indicated in patients with suspected acute cholecystitis. If the etiology of symptoms is unclear or ultrasound is not diagnostic, a CT may be performed. CT is also useful in the evaluation of potential complications of acute cholecystitis (e.g. gallbladder perforation or emphysematous cholecystitis). CT findings of acute chloecystitis include gallstones, gallbladder distention, thickening of the gallbladder wall, pericholecystic inflammation and fluid. CT is only 75% sensitive for the detection of cholelithiasis. The most specific finding is pericholecystic inflammation. Major criteria for acute cholecystitis include calculi, thickened gallbladder wall, pericholecystic fluid and subserosal edema. Minor criteria include gallbladder distention and sludge. The diagnosis can be made by one major and two minor criteria.
ACR Code

7.2
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Inflammatory, non-infectious
Keywords

Computed tomography
cholecystitis
CT
Reference

Bennett, G. and Balthazar, E. “Ultrasound and CT evaluation of emergent gallbladder pathology”. Radiologic Clinics of North America. 2003. 1203-1216.
( This topic was added on 2005-05-12 and last edited on 2005-05-29 )

T-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)
History

2 year old boy presents with a rapid decline in mental status
Exam

• Mildly febrile
• Difficult to arouse
• White count 860,000
• Thrombocytopenia
Findings

Multiple enhancing masses involving both cerebral hemispheres and the brain stem.
Differential Diagnosis

• Cerebral abscesses
• Metastatic disease
• Cerebral infarction

T-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)
Diagnosis By

Hematologic evaluation

Chemotherapy

CASE
Rhabdomyosarcoma
History

6 y.o. girl
Findings

CT shows a very large heterogeneous mass filling the abdomen and extending into the pelvis. The mass causes secondary bilateral hydronephrosis and does not appear to originate from the kidneys or the liver.
Differential Diagnosis

Rhabdomyosarcoma Burkitt lymphoma Neuroblastoma Leiomyosarcoma (if older) Ovarian tumor Sacrococcygeal teratoma (if associated with sacrum/coccyx)
Case Diagnosis

Rhabdomyosarcoma

case_details_text:
CASE
Right Sided Diverticulitis
History

55 yo white female presents with fever, right lower quadrant pain for 2 days. No significant PMH Please rule out Appendicitis per ER request
Exam

Tenderness to palpation in the RLQ, no rebound tenderness. White Blood Cell count 12.7, temp 101.
Findings

Single inflamed diverticulum of the right colon, with secondary inflammation of the base of the appendix but a normal distal appendix.
Differential Diagnosis

Appendicitis Right Sided diverticulitis Inflammatory Bowel Disease Tumor with perforation.
Case Diagnosis

Right Sided Diverticulitis
Diagnosis By

CT appearance
Treatment & Follow Up

Treated medically with resolution
Discussion

Right sided diverticulitis is unusual, though more prevelant in people of Southeast Asian decent. In this case, the only diverticulum seen was the inflamed example in the right colon.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Diverticulosis And Diverticulitis
Disease Discussion

Most are false diverticula (herniations of mucosa only, rather than a full-thickness outpouching). This is a disease of "developed" countries, with an incidence approaching 50%. The hypothesis is: high-fiber, high-volume feces => low pressure defecation. High-pressure in colon may produce the diverticuli, by herniation at the natural weakness along the taenia coli, where vessels enter. Complications include stagnation leading to microbial invasion (diverticulitis) and fistulization.
ACR Code

7.2
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Diverticulum
( This topic was added on 1998-02-16 and last edited on 2004-07-13 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Appendicitis
History

18-year-old female with right lower quadrant abdominal pain.
Exam

Tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Positive rebound tenderness and guarding. WBC 14.3, HGB 14.0, HCT 41.1, PLT 271, NEUT 77.1%, LYMPH 11.5%, MONO 9.7%, EOS 1%, HCG QL negative.
Findings

Intravenous- and enteric contrast-enhanced axial computed tomographic images of the abdomen demonstrate a distended appendix (9 mm diameter) with thickened, enhancing walls. The lumen of the appendix fails to opacify with enteric contrast. There is prominent peri-appendiceal fat stranding without peri-appendiceal fluid collection or free air.
Differential Diagnosis

Acute appendicitis
Case Diagnosis

appendicitis
Diagnosis By

Characteristic physical examination and computed tomographic findings. The patient underwent appendectomy and the specimen was submitted to the pathology department for examination ("final diagnosis: - acute appendicitis").
Treatment & Follow Up

Appendectomy.
Discussion

None.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Appendicitis
Disease Discussion

Acute appendicitis usually develops as a result of obstruction of the appendiceal lumen. Obstruction may be the result of lymphoid hyperplasia, which is the cause in approximately 60% of people. Other causes may be accumulation of fecal material (35%), and less commonly foreign body obstruction. As the appendix distends, the visceral peritoneum stretches and causes poorly localized pain in the periumbilical region. As the infection progresses parietal peritoneal irritation causes more localized pain.
ACR Code

7.2
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Inflammatory, NOS
( This topic was added on 2001-07-25 and last edited on 2002-01-20 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Stage V Bilateral Wilms' Tumor
History

5 year female with a single episode of painless hematuria which rapidly progressed to clots of blood over two days. She initially presented to the emergency room. She was instructed to follow up the next day to her primary care provider. She returned to the emergency room the next morning with right upper quadrant pain and vomiting and was found to have a right abdominal mass. A CT scan was performed at that time demonstrating bilateral renal masses as described in the images.
Exam

Right abdominal mass that did not cross the midline. UA- 2+ proteinuria, gross hematuria
Findings

Bilateral heterogeneously enhancing renal masses with tumor thrombus extending into the right renal vein, IVC, and the right atrium. Bilateral neuroblastomatosis is demonstrated.
Differential Diagnosis

Bilateral Wilms tumor, nephroblastomatosis
Case Diagnosis

Stage V bilateral Wilms' Tumor
Diagnosis By

Bilateral renal biopsies, both showing favorable histology Wilm's tumor. No nuclear anaplasia was seen.
Treatment & Follow Up

After initial chemotherapy decreased the size, but did not eliminate the right atrial tumor thrombus, the pt. underwent thoracotomy to remove it. Later she underwent right nephrectomy when the largest right renal mass grew despite initial reponse to chemotherapy. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy continue to treat residual disease on the left.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Bilateral Wilms' Tumor
Disease Discussion

Wilms' tumor is the most common primary renal malignancy and intra-abdominal tumor of childhood. Ninety per cent occur in children less than 7 years of age, with a median age of 3-1/2 years. The children are usually asymptomatic, most often presenting with clinical suspicion of an abdominal mass (approximately 70%). Other symptoms include abdominal pain (30%), hematuria (15 to 20%), and less commonly with moderately severe hypertension and nonspecific constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, gastrointestinal complaints). There is a higher incidence of Wilms' tumor in patients with certain congenital abnormalities such as aniridia, hemi-hypertrophy, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, nephroblastomatosis, and various genitourinary abnormalities (hypoplasia, fusion, ectopia, duplicated collecting systems, hypospadias, and cryptorchidism). Wilms' tumor is secondary to proliferation of metanephric blastema. It is typically bulky and usually extends within the renal parenchyma, displacing and distorting the pelvocalyceal system. However, the mass may be exophytic or may, although rarely, be extrarenal. The outcome following multimodal therapy depends on the initial stage and whether or not the tumor has favorable or unfavorable histology for response to treatment. The unfavorable types include anaplastic, sarcomatous, and rhabdoid types. The following stages have been described for Wilms' tumor: I: Tumor limited to kidney and completely resected, negative margins, intact renal capsule, not rupture. II: Tumor extends beyond kidney, but completely excised, negative margins, regional infiltration, spillage. III: Residual nonhematogenous tumor, confined to abdomen including lymph nodes, peritoneal implants, incomplete excision. IV: Hematogenous metastases beyond stage III, i.e., lung, liver, bone, brain. V: Bilateral renal involvement, at time of diagnosis. Wilms' tumor is bilateral (Stage V) in 5 to 10% at time of initial diagnosis. In a patient with unilateral Wilms', a contralateral tumor may develop 5 to 10 years later, although the majority occur within 2 years. The work-up should include a plain abdominal supine radiograph, not only to look for mass affect but also to look for calcifications, skeletal abnormalities, and paravertebral masses which may help in differentiating Wilms' tumor from neuroblastoma. The next imaging study should be abdominal and pelvic sonography to determine the organ of origin, the size and extent of the mass, the characteristics of the mass (solid, cystic, complex calcifications), the presence of regional lymphadenopathy, liver metastases, tumor thrombus in the renal vein, inferior vena cava, and/or right atrium, and to look for bilaterality of the mass. One should also look for any evidence of nephroblastomatosis which appears sonographically as hypoechoic masses in the periphery of the kidney, thickening of the renal capsule, or as nodularity or lobulation of the kidney. This entity, which may be an anlage for Wilms' tumor, is much more easily seen with contrast- enhanced CT. Duplex and/or color Doppler imaging are particularly helpful in the evaluation of the venous vasculature structures that may be involved with Wilms' tumor. Wilms' tumor is most often a solid mass, although cystic spaces may often be seen within the mass due to internal hemorrhage and/or necrosis. We have noted that some of the cystic spaces within Wilms' tumor are large venous channels due to arteriovenous shunting. Depending upon the sophistication of the ultrasound, one may choose to also obtain a baseline CT, unless nephroblastomatosis is suspected. Certainly a baseline chest CT is recommended prior to surgery to look for pulmonary metastases. During and after their treatment, sonography is an excellent noninvasive means of following the children.
ACR Code

8.3
Location

Genitourinary
Category

Neoplasm, NOS
( This topic was added on 2001-05-21 and last edited on 2004-06-06 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Child Abuse/Non-Accidental Trauma
History

4 month old baby girl brought to the ER after an acute life threatening event.
Exam

Not known.
Findings

• Axial CT image demonstrates bilateral extraaxial subdural fluid collections which aremore prominent along the frontal convexities. These have a slightly increased attenuation when compared with the CSF, and are consistent with chronic subdural hematomas. In addition there is a linear density within the left subdural space and along the falx posteriorly consistent with an acute subdural hematoma.
• Multiple MR images confirm the presence of bilateral subdural hematomas of differing signal intensities consistent with acute on chronic subdurals
Differential Diagnosis

• Accidental Trauma
• Non-accidental trauma (Child Abuse)
Case Diagnosis

Child abuse/Non-accidental trauma
Diagnosis By

History and imaging
Discussion

This case demonstrates the utility of MRI in evaluating the presence/extent of edema present in cases of non-accidental head trauma. The presence of the subdural hemorrhages is evident on CT. However, there was no evidence of edema (i.e. loss of gray-white differentiation, sulcal effacement, or reversal sign). Subsequent MRI revealed diffuse white matter restricted diffusion with corresponding increased T2 signal (out of proportion of the patient's stage of myelination) consistent with diffuse white matter cytotoxic edema.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Child Abuse, Nonaccidental Trauma
Disease Discussion

Child abuse/nonaccidental trauma (NAT) is an unfortunate common occurrence in the United States with an estimate of 1 out of every 100 children falling victim. An estimated 1200 children die each year as a result of their injuries. The radiologist plays an important role in the diagnosis of child abuse, and therefore a clear understanding of characteristic imaging findings is crucial. The metaphyseal fracture is considered the most specific radiographic finding. Other concerning findings include rib fractures, extraaxial hemorrhage, shear brain injuries, vertebral compression fractures, and small bowel injuries. CT and MRI are most useful in detecting intracranial injuries. Common injuries seen with abuse include subdural hemorrhage, subarachnoid hemorrhage, shear (axonal) injury, contusion, and cerebral edema.
ACR Code

1.4
Location

Brain and Neuro
Category

Trauma
Keywords

nonaccidental trauma
child abuse

Reference

Lonergan GJ, et al. Child abuse: Radiologic-Pathologic Correlation. Radiographics. 2003: 23(4); 811-845.
( This topic was added on 2007-09-07 and last edited on 2007-09-12 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Cerebral Infarction (Basilar Artery Territory) Secondary To Calcified Embolus From Heart
History

71 year old woman presents to ER comatose, transferred from an outside hospital. History of diabetes, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation.
Exam

Coma. Responds to deep pain only.
Findings

• Calcified embolus distal basilar artery on CT and CTA.
• Multiple infarcts involving the thalami, left occipital lobe, brainstem and left cerebellar hemisphere.
Differential Diagnosis

• Brain infarction
• Calcified thrombus
• Embolized calcified plaque or cardiac valve vegetation
Case Diagnosis

Cerebral infarction (basilar artery territory) secondary to calcified embolus from heart
Diagnosis By

History, Physical Examination, MRI and CT scans
Treatment & Follow Up

Supportive only. Sadly, this patient died two days after presentation.
( This case was added on 2011-09-09 )

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Cerebral Infarction (Stroke)
Disease Discussion

Cerebral infarction is one kind of stroke with tissue death that can be caused by any process that stops cellular metabolism. Most often this is vascular, caused by a reduction or interruption of normal blood flow. Infarction can also be caused by poisons and toxins (hexacholorophene, cyanide), low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), low oxygen (hypoxia), carbon monoxide (shifts the Hgb dissociation curve) etc. Vascular causes of cerebral infarction are usually produced by arterial occlusions from an in situ thrombus or an embolus. Arterial infarctions usually follow known patterns of perfusion from blood flow maps (see link and diagram below}. Venous occlusion causes infarction through stagnation and accumulation of deoxygenated blood in the brain. Venous infarcts have extremely variable patterns, and may be bilateral (e.g. after superior sagittal sinus thrombosis). Venous infarction often produces a significant deep and irregular parenchymal hemorrhage.
ACR Code

1.-1
Location

Brain and Neuro
Category

Vascular
External Links

rad.usuhs.mil/rad/stroke/index.html
( This topic was added on 2000-02-26 and last edited on 2001-09-27 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Pneumatosis Cystoides Intestinalis - Idiopathic
History

A 64 year old male with microscopic hematuria
Exam

None provided
Findings

Incidentally noted there is a significant amount of air present within the walls of multiple bowel loops, with associated pneumoperitoneum.
Differential Diagnosis

Bowel ischemia Iatrogenic from prior intervention Idiopathic
Case Diagnosis

Pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis - Idiopathic
Diagnosis By

Imaging findings along with further patient history revealing that he did not have any abdominal pain and upon subsequent imaging the pneumatosis and pneumoperitonium resolved without intervention.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Pneumatosis Cystoides Intestinalis
Disease Discussion

Pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis represents multiple noncommunicating, thin-walled gas-filled cysts within the wall of the intestines. It may appear as curvilinear, linear or round collections of air which can range in size from several mm to greater than 1 cm in size. It occurs when there has been damage of the bowel mucosa and passage of gas into the wall produced by bacterial superinfection. Primary pneumatosis occurs in 15% of cases and has no identifiable cause. Secondary pneumatosis accounts for 85% of cases with varied etiologies. The more common etiologies are COPD, intestinal obstruction, intestinal ischemia, and infection. It is seen more commonly in the large colon involving the mesenteric side of the bowel wall. All wall layers may be affected, with the most common being the subserosal and submucosal layers. Associated findings include pneumoperitoneum and gas within the portal and mesenteric vessels. The presence of which does not always indicate poor prognosis. The prognosis varies widely from spontaneous resolution to a fatal outcome depending largely upon the etiology.
ACR Code

7.2
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Inflammatory, NOS
Keywords

pneumatosis


Reference

Brant and Helms, Requisites, Dahnert
( This topic was added on 2001-09-23 and last edited on 2004-08-17 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Pneumoperitoneum
History

Recent surgical removal of abdominal mass.
Exam

Non-contributory.
Findings

Free air noted under the right hemidiaphragm and anterior subcutaneous air seen on the lateral view. Also noted is mild blunting of both costophrenic angles, likely representing either atelectasis or sympathetic pleural effusions.
Differential Diagnosis

Pneumoperitoneum Ruptured abdominal viscus Post operative air
Case Diagnosis

Pneumoperitoneum
Diagnosis By

Surgical history and classic imaging findings.
Treatment & Follow Up

Spontaneous resorption of intraperitoneal air usually requires no direct intervention or followup.
Discussion

If this patient did not have a recent surgical history, the presence of free intraperitoneal air would be an ominous sign suggestive of a perforated viscus. This would then become a surgical urgency or emergency.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Pneumoperitoneum
Disease Discussion

Free intraperitoneal air is a normal consequence of abdominal surgery, including endoscopic procdures. In a patient without an iatrogenic cause and in the appropriate clinical setting, the finding of free air in the peritoneal cavity indicates a possible perforation of a hollow viscus - often a surgical emergency. There are many plain radiographic signs available for identification of free air. The upright chest radiograph is a common method for looking for free air under the hemidiaphragms, especially the right hemidiaphragm. (see case below) In the very ill patient, upright films may not be available. A left lateral decubitus view may provide the next best alternative, with air floating along the upright side. Supine views are the least sensitive, and a cross table lateral may be the only alternative to help with the evaluation. Some signs of free air which can be helpful on supine radiographs are the finding of increased lucency over the liver (liver density less than that of the heart), air outlining both the inner and outer walls of the bowel (Rigler's sign) and the finding of air outlining the falciform ligament (Football sign). If upright or decubitus films are obtained, technically it is important that the patient be placed in this position for 10-15 minutes prior to the film being exposed so that the free air has a chance to rise to the non-dependent location.
ACR Code

791.71
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Differential Diagnosis
Keywords

pneumoperitoneum


( This topic was added on 2001-06-19 and last edited on 2004-08-25 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Vertebral Artery Dissection With Cerebellar Infarcts
History

38 year old woman with 10 year history of SLE (Lupus). She presents now with a 1 week history of headache, left sided numbness, and nausea. No trauma
Exam

Non contibutory
Findings

Short section irregular contour right proximal vertebral artery with intraluminal filling defect. Multiple small right cerebellar infarcts.
Differential Diagnosis

• Fibromuscular Dysplasia
• Vasculitis
• Thrombosis
• Dissection
Case Diagnosis

Vertebral Artery Dissection with Cerebellar Infarcts
Diagnosis By

Imaging
Treatment & Follow Up

Anticoagulation and Plavix
Discussion

The MRA was interpreted as normal. Only after the catheter angiogram was the right vertebral luminal irregularity appreciated on the MRA.
( This case was added on 2012-06-01 )

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Vertebral Artery Dissection
Disease Discussion

Vertebral artery dissections may occur after head and neck trauma or spontaneously. Cervical artery dissections, including vertebral and carotid arteries, are the leading cause of stroke in patients under 45. In adults, there is no predominance between men and women. Common clinical features associated with vertebral artery dissection include neck pain, headache (often posterior/occipital), Horner syndrome, tinnitus, audible bruits, or symptoms of TIA/stroke. A dissection of the artery can occur between the media and adventitia, between the intima and media, or a combination of both. The dissection can result with stenosis, occlusion, aneurysmal dilation, intraluminal thrombus formation, or extravascular hemorrhage. Radiographic evaluation for vertebral artery dissection can be complicated by false negatives and false positives. The most common radiographic techniques used for evaluation include CT and MR. Common causes of false positives include turbulent flow simulating stenosis or adjacent structures that mimic hematoma, or patient body habitus. False negatives are often related to lack of inclusion of the affected area in the study field. Often times, evaluation of headache which may be secondary to dissection results in imaging of the head without inclusion of the neck, although the majority of vertebral dissections occur in the cervical neck. Treatment for vertebral artery dissection often involves antiplatelet or anticoagulation therapy. The highest risk of ischemia secondary to dissection is in the first several days after the dissection occurs. Repeat imaging to confirm stability and/or revascularization is recommended prior to discontinuing treatment.
ACR Code

2.0
Location

Head and Neck (ex. orbit)
Category

Ischemia, Ischemic Infarction
Keywords

Vertebral artery dissection
cervical artery dissection
cerebral ischemia
Reference

Daniel D. Federman, M.D., Elizabeth G. Nabel, MD, eds. 2011. ACP Medicine. Hamilton, Ontario & Philadelphia, PA. Decker Publishing Inc. ISSN 1547-1659. STAT!Ref Online Electronic Medical Library.
http://online.statref.com.proxy.lib.umich.edu/document.aspx?fxid=48&docid=1886. 6/22/2011 12:35:16 PM CDT (UTC -05:00). Fusco, Matthew R MD; Harrigan, Mark R MD. Cerebrovascular Dissections—A Review Part I: Spontaneous Dissections. Neurosurgery. 2011;68(1):242-257 Provenzale JM, Sarikaya B, Hacein-Bey L, Wintermark M. Causes of misinterpretation of cross-sectional imaging studies for dissection of the craniocervical arteries. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2011 Jan;196(1):45-52.
( This topic was added on 2011-06-22 and last edited on 2011-06-23 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Moderately Differentiated Adenocarcinoma (Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer)
History

42 yo male with abdominal pain
Findings

Acute abdominal series demonstrates a normal PA chest radiograph without subdiaphragmatic free air. There are differential air fluid levels in the mid-abdomen, with dilated loops of small bowel. There is a paucity of bowel gas projecting over the rectum, and stool is noted in the RLQ. Contrast enhanced axial CT images through the abdomen demonstrate a bulky, irregular heterogeneous cecal mass with pericolic inflammation and asymmetric wall thickening. Multiple dilated fluid filled loops of small bowel are noted, some of which contain air fluid levels. Additionally, there is fecalization of the terminal ileum. The appendix is normal.
Differential Diagnosis

Adenocarcinoma (Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer) Lymphoma Metastasis Carcinoid Tumor GIST Diverticulitis Crohn’s Disease Typhlitis (Neutropenic Colitis) Ischemic Necrosis of the Cecum (rare – patients with a history of cardiac failure and arrhythmia). Reference: Hoeffel et al. RadioGraphics 2006;26:1373-1390.
Case Diagnosis

Moderately Differentiated Adenocarcinoma (Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer)
Diagnosis By

The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy and subsequent subtotal colectomy. Pathologic evaluation of the surgical specimen demonstrated a 10.1 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma involving the cecum. 0/24 lymph nodes were positive for metastasis, the appendix and ileal mucosa were normal.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer
Disease Discussion

Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) is also known as Lynch syndrome, of which, there are two types. Lynch I has no history of associated cancers. Lynch II often presents with other cancers most commonly of ovarian or uterine origin. Both types are predisposed to a higher frequency of proximal colonic tumors with advanced pathology compared to typical colon cancer. HNPCC typically presents during the fourth and fifth decades and characterized by adenomas that progress much more rapidly to carcinoma than typical. These are not as numerous as those in Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). It also has a more heterogenous genetic basis than FAP, with most cases linked to chromosomes 2,3, and 7. As such, the diagnosis is often based upon familial history of early colorectal cancer presentations (prior to 50 years of age). Genetic testing is often difficult secondary to multiple site mutations and is positive in approximately 80% of affected individuals. However, agressive surveillance of all first degree relatives of individuals clinically suspected to have the syndrome is warranted. Screening should begin at age 20 to 25 consist of colonoscopy every other year. Alternatively, genetically positive individuals should be considered for prophylactic colectomy. Affected females should consider early childbearing followed by prophylactic total abdominal hyterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy. Imaging characteristics are those of the respective cancers. In the case of colon cancer, it often presents as an intraluminal filling defect with bowel wall thickening and adjacent inflammation (fat stranding). It is often focal and is frequently accompanied by adjacent lymphadenopathy. It can be difficult to differentiate this entity from diverticulitis which can also present with similar findings. However, the wall thickening and pericolonic inflammation are more likely to be focal in colon cancer, whereas it more likely to involve larger segments in diverticulitis (greater than 10 CM). Also, diverticulitis is much less likely to have associated lymphadenopathy and intaluminal mass.
ACR Code

7.3
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Neoplasm, carcinoma
Keywords

hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer
HNPCC
Lynch syndrome
Reference

Abeloff: Clinical Oncology, 2nd ed., copyright 2000, Churchill Livingstone, Inc. Chintapalli,et al., Diverticulitis versus Colon Cancer: Differentiation with Helical CT findings., Radiology, 1999: 210; 429-435, RSNA, 1999.
( This topic was added on 2004-04-29 and last edited on 2004-07-02 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Acute Pancreatitis
History

54 year old male with persistent fevers, leukocytosis, and low grade abdominal pain.
Exam

Temp: 100.8 Abd exam: +BS, Soft, -TTP, No rebound. Wbc 14.5k
Findings

Diffuse enlargement of the pancreas with blurring of margins. Stranding densities in the surrounding fat and blurring of the fat planes are also noted.
Differential Diagnosis

Multiple etiologies of acute pancreatitis include: EtOH Gallstones Metabolic Trauma (including iatrogenesis) Penetrating ulcer Malignancy
Case Diagnosis

Acute pancreatitis
Diagnosis By

Elevated amylase and lipase noted following exam.
Treatment & Follow Up

Laboratory follow up after supportive treatment demonstrated normalization of amylase and lipase.
Discussion

While the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is made clinically, in this case, the patient's relatively mild symptoms did not raise suspicion for pancreatitis until after abdominal imaging. The main role of CT imaging in the setting of pancreatitis is to evaluate for the presence of complications such as pseudocyst or abscess formation, hemorrhage, necrosis, or splenic vein thrombosis. Definitive identification of precipitating cause was not identified in the patient. Acute pancreatitis may be considered idiopathic in up to 20% of cases.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Acute Pancreatitis
Disease Discussion

Alcoholism and biliary tract disease account for the vast majority of cases of acute pancreatitis in adults in the United States. In mild acute edematous pancreatitis, the gland is swollen and edematous but otherwise well-preserved. Normal structure and function can return after resolution. Moderate-to-severe acute pancreatitis, as in this case, is characterized by proteolytic destruction of pancreatic parenchyma, hemorrhage from blood vessel wall necrosis, fat necrosis, and accompanying inflammation which may be widespread in the abdominal cavity. Secondary bacterial infection may occur after 3 to 4 days resulting in suppurative necrosis or abscess formation. If the patient survives acute phlegmonous pancreatitis, the end result may be pancreatic fibrosis, calcification and duct dilatation. Severe upper abdominal pain in a band-like distribution sometimes radiating to the back is almost always present. Elevation of serum amylase and lipase are characteristic although not completely specific. RADIOLOGY: The sonographic and/or CT appearance of the pancreas is normal in about 30% of patients with the clinical diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. When pancreatic abnormality is present, it may be diffuse or focal, and when focal usually involves the head or the tail. SONOGRAPHY: The involved area is usually but not always hypoechoic due to the presence of edema. There may be pancreatic ductal dilatation associated with focal enlargement of the head of the pancreas. In mild pancreatitis the swelling of the gland and dilatation of the pancreatic duct usually subside within days to weeks as the echogenicity of the parenchyma returns to normal. A phlegmon is a spreading diffuse inflammatory edema of soft tissues usually accompanied by pancreatic fluid and usually emanating from the body and tail. Spread usually occurs in an anterior direction into the area of the lesser sac and anterior pararenal spaces. More posterior extension is usually prevented by the anterior pararenal fascia (Gerota's fascia). The phlegmon may involve the right anterior pararenal space and may simulate gallbladder disease by producing thickening of the gallbladder wall and a pericholecystic fluid collection. Extension may also occur into the transverse mesocolon and small bowel mesentery and inferiorly into the retroperitoneum and pelvis. A phlegmonous mass is hypoechoic and has fairly good through transmission whereas a peripancreatic fluid collection is relatively anechoic with excellent through transmission. The sonographic appearance of pancreatic hemorrhage varies with its age; acutely the hemorrhage can appear homogeneously echogenic. The degree of echogenicity decreases with time and so the mass assumes a complex appearance, and by 3-5 days the area of hemorrhage is sonolucent. CT: The gland may be focally or diffusely enlarged, and the involved portion may have a well-defined outline or its interface with the peripancreatic fat may be ill-defined. The attenuation number of the involved pancreas is reduced on non-contrast scans, presumably secondary to the presence of edema, and it is the spread of this edema into the surrounding fat that gives the pancreatic outline its indistinct appearance. Peripancreatic phlegmons are fairly low attenuation on unenhanced scans but enhance with intravenous contrast whereas their accompanying peripancreatic fluid collections do not. The pancreatic parenchyma will also enhance with intravenous contrast, so that contrast enhanced scans give a better distinction between gland, fluid and phlegmon than unenhanced scans. CT gives a better global depiction of the extent of pancreatitis than sonography. CT can make the specific diagnosis of hemorrhagic pancreatitis when high attenuation values (50-75H) are present in the phlegmon. However, these high density numbers will only persist for 24-48 hr after the initial event. When hemorrhagic pancreatitis is suspected, a CT should be performed immediately with a preliminary non-contrast scan as intravenous contrast may obscure the high density of a hemorrhage. Pseudoaneurysms can occur secondary to acute pancreatitis and most commonly involve the splenic artery but can involve other branches of the celiac axis, the superior mesenteric artery or intrapancreatic arteries. Doppler sonography or dynamic CT should be performed whenever this complication is suspected.
ACR Code

7.-1
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Inflammatory, NOS
( This topic was added on 2001-04-05 and last edited on 2001-04-30 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Brain, Cerebral Abscess With Cultures Postive For Streptococcus.
History

20 year old man presents with his first time seizure. No history of drug abuse, cardiac disease, sinusitis or dental caries.
Exam

• No fever.
• Mildly elevated sedimentation rate (ESR).
• Negative cardiac ultrasound.
• No dental infections.
Findings

• Ring enhancing lesion right frontal lobe with edema.
• Ring is low signal on T2 images.
• DWI images reveal restricted diffusion.
Differential Diagnosis

Glioma Metastatic disease Lymphoma
Case Diagnosis

Brain, cerebral abscess with cultures postive for streptococcus.
Diagnosis By

Surgical drainage
Treatment & Follow Up

IV antibiotics following surgical drainage.
Discussion

No source for abscess detected.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Brain, Cerebral Abscess
Disease Discussion

Patients with cerebral abscess often present with headache, fever and neurologic signs related to the location of the abscess. They form from areas of cerebritis that may initially present on imaging as an ill-defined region of edema. After progression to abscess occurs, they typically present radiographically as a ring-enhancing lesion. A thin rim of enhancement and hypodense center are seen on CT. MR images will demonstrate hypointensity of the rim on T2 images with avid enhancement on post-contrast T1 images. Restricted diffusion will be present. Cerebral abscess is most commonly caused by pyogenic bacteria. Routes of bacterial spread to the CSF include direct extension from infected sinuses, direct infection status post trauma and from hematogenous sources (to include right to left shunts). The differential diagnosis for ring-lesions includes metastatic deposits, necrotic primary neoplasm such as GBM, resolving hematoma, and tumefactive demyelination. A thin capsule rim, restricted diffusion and spectroscopy findings of increased lactate and amino acids help to establish abscess as the diagnosis. Treatment of the lesion depends on size. While small lesions may be adequately treated with systemic antibiotics alone, large lesions may require stereotactic aspiration or drainage. Follow up using DWI:
http://www.ajnr.org/cgi/content/full/25/8/1310
ACR Code

1.2
Location

Brain and Neuro
Category

Infection, bacteria
Keywords

brain abscess
ring enhancement
diffusion
Reference

Fischbein NJ, Dillon WP, Barkovich AJ. Teaching Atlas of Brain Imaging. New York. Thieme; 2000. pp 153-156.
External Links

www.ajnr.org/cgi/content/full/25/8/1310
( This topic was added on 2003-04-10 and last edited on 2009-04-21 )

CASE
Rosette Forming Glioneuronal Tumor Of The Pineal Gland
History

33 year old woman presents with a 1 month history of headaches and visual complaints
Exam

Non-contributory
Findings

• Pineal region mass.
• No enhancement, no calcification, nor hemorrhagic component.
Differential Diagnosis

• Pineocytoma
• Pineoblastoma
• Germinoma
• Lymphoma
Case Diagnosis

Rosette Forming Glioneuronal Tumor of the Pineal Gland
Diagnosis By

Surgery and pathological examination
Treatment & Follow Up

Surgical resection only.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Rosette Forming Glioneuronal Tumor Of The Pineal Gland
Disease Discussion

Rosette Forming Glioneuronal Tumor of the Pineal Gland is a newly designated pathological entity which is found primarily in young patients. It has two distinct cell populations which consists of pilocytic astrocytoma cells and cells which form neurocytic rosettes. The latter cells contain minimal cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei. PMID: 19941371 These lesions are typically non-aggressive usually classified as WHO Grade 1 tumors. These tumors may involve the pineal gland, tectal plate and thalami. They typically do not enhance on MRI.
ACR Code

1.3
Location

Brain and Neuro
Category

Neoplasm, malignant (NOS)
Keywords

pineocytoma pineoplastoma
mixed glial neuronal tumors
Pineal gland
Reference

Oncology of CNS Tumors 10.1007/978-3-642-02874-6_11 Diagnositic Cytopathology 1097-0339, 2009
External Links

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?db=pubmed&cmd=link&linkname=pubmed_pubmed&uid=19941371
( This topic was added on 2010-04-30 and last edited on 2010-05-05 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Giant Intracranial Aneurysm, Partially Thrombosed
History

64 year old woman presents with a sudden onset of headache and visual problems
Exam

Non contributory
Findings

CT: Hyperdense mass in suprasellar cistern
Differential Diagnosis

Pituitary adenoma Pituitary apoplexy Meningioma Metastatic disease Giant Aneurysm
Case Diagnosis

Giant intracranial aneurysm, partially thrombosed
Diagnosis By

MR and Angiography
Treatment & Follow Up

The aneurysm was coiled with endovascular technique.
Discussion

Due to the restricted diffusion on MRI neurosurgical staff was concerned that the lesion was an Epidermoid Cyst. Angiography led them to the proper diagnosis.
( This case was added on 2013-09-05 )

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Giant Intracranial Aneurysm
Disease Discussion

Giant intracranial aneurysms are most commonly defined as greater than 25 mm. These aneurysms may obtain sizes much greater than this (Film .4). Giant intracranial aneurysms comprise 2.5-5% of all intracranial aneurysms. They are more common in women (3:1) between 30-60 years of age. The clinical presentation is most frequently as a local mass with headaches, visual loss, cranial nerve dysfunction, pyramidal tract signs and seizures being the most typical initial symptoms. Subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to rupture of giant aneurysms is relatively uncommon, although it does occur. The base of the brain is a common site for giant aneurysms, with 43% involving the cavernous internal carotid artery. Pinto et al described three CT patterns of giant aneurysms: nonthrombosed, partially thrombosed, and thrombosed. The most specific pattern is encountered in partially thrombosed aneurysms, which have a "target" appearance on contrast-enhanced CT scans (Film .5). Nonthrombosed aneurysms are slightly hyperdense before contrast administration and enhance markedly with contrast (Films .1 and .2). Calcium may be found in a nonuniform distribution within the mass or in its periphery. Angiography usually establishes the correct diagnosis of giant aneurysm and excludes other diagnostic possibilities such as meningioma, craniopharyngioma or pituitary adenoma. Spontaneous, complete thrombosis of giant aneurysms may occur in up to 20% of cases, obscuring the diagnosis, even with angiography. Angiography, which only directly visualizes the nonthrombosed patent lumen, may severely underestimate the size of giant aneurysms. Film .6 is the AP angiogram from the same patient in Film .5. Only the small, nonthrombosed portion of this giant aneurysm is opacified, the thrombosed portion producing avascular mass effect. Olsen et al reported MR evidence of intraluminal blood flow in 12 of 15 cases of giant aneurysm. These cases showed luminal signal void (Film .7). Other flow effects, such as even-echo rephasing, were also seen. Partially or totally thrombosed giant aneurysms will demonstrate a medium to high signal intensity within the lumen on T1- and T2-weighted images (Film .7). Calcification of the aneurysm wall is better seen on CT.
ACR Code

1.-1
Location

Generalized
Category

Vascular
( This topic was added on 2001-03-21 and last edited on 2001-07-02 )

Disease Discussion
Giant intracranial aneurysms are most commonly defined as greater than 25 mm. These aneurysms may obtain sizes much greater than this (Film .4). Giant intracranial aneurysms comprise 2.5-5% of all intracranial aneurysms. They are more common in women (3:1) between 30-60 years of age. The clinical presentation is most frequently as a local mass with headaches, visual loss, cranial nerve dysfunction, pyramidal tract signs and seizures being the most typical initial symptoms. Subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to rupture of giant aneurysms is relatively uncommon, although it does occur. The base of the brain is a common site for giant aneurysms, with 43% involving the cavernous internal carotid artery. Pinto et al described three CT patterns of giant aneurysms: nonthrombosed, partially thrombosed, and thrombosed. The most specific pattern is encountered in partially thrombosed aneurysms, which have a "target" appearance on contrast-enhanced CT scans (Film .5). Nonthrombosed aneurysms are slightly hyperdense before contrast administration and enhance markedly with contrast (Films .1 and .2). Calcium may be found in a nonuniform distribution within the mass or in its periphery. Angiography usually establishes the correct diagnosis of giant aneurysm and excludes other diagnostic possibilities such as meningioma, craniopharyngioma or pituitary adenoma. Spontaneous, complete thrombosis of giant aneurysms may occur in up to 20% of cases, obscuring the diagnosis, even with angiography. Angiography, which only directly visualizes the nonthrombosed patent lumen, may severely underestimate the size of giant aneurysms. Film .6 is the AP angiogram from the same patient in Film .5. Only the small, nonthrombosed portion of this giant aneurysm is opacified, the thrombosed portion producing avascular mass effect. Olsen et al reported MR evidence of intraluminal blood flow in 12 of 15 cases of giant aneurysm. These cases showed luminal signal void (Film .7). Other flow effects, such as even-echo rephasing, were also seen. Partially or totally thrombosed giant aneurysms will demonstrate a medium to high signal intensity within the lumen on T1- and T2-weighted images (Film .7). Calcification of the aneurysm wall is better seen on CT.
ACR Code
1.-1
Location
Generalized
Category
Vascular

case_details_text:
CASE
Pneumobilia
History

45 year old woman with history of painless jaundice and recent common bile duct stenting.
Exam

Mild right upper quadrant tenderness with otherwise unremarkable physical examination. The liver transaminases were mildly elevated.
Findings

The axial CT images of the abdomen demonstrate the presence of a common bile duct stent with proximal portion near the cystic duct and distal portion in the duodenum. There is an air/fluid level in the gall bladder and air within the hepatic biliary system.
Differential Diagnosis

Differential diagnosis includes pneumobilia from infection, recent surgical procedure such as sphincterotomy or stenting or fistula formation between bowel and the gall bladder.
Case Diagnosis

Pneumobilia
Diagnosis By

Radiographically.
Treatment & Follow Up

Air in the gall bladder can be an expected finding after stenting or surgical procedure and does not require treatment. Pneumobilia from cholecystitis is a much more serious finding for which urgent surgical referral is warranted.
Discussion

This patient underwent an MRCP prior to stenting which did not reveal the presence of a common bile duct stone. Further imaging eventually led to the discovery of a pancreatic head mass requiring surgical excision.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Pneumobilia
Disease Discussion

Air found within the biliary tree is most commonly caused by sphincterotomy or recent gallstone passage. Other causes include cholecystoenterostomy or choledochoenterostomy, emphysematous cholecystitis (Diabetic population), trauma, enteric fistula. Unlike portal venous gas, the distribution of pneumobilia is more central and confluent. Portal venous gas can be seen with bowel ischemia.
ACR Code

7.7
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Differential Diagnosis
Keywords

Pneumobilia
air
biliary

case_details_text:
CASE
Diverticulitis
History

54 year old female is brought to the emergency room with severe left lower quadrant pain. The patient reports several prior incidents of similar pain and had previously been treated with antibiotics.
Exam

The patient's temperature is 99.8 F. She is slightly tachycardic with a heart rate of 104. Her other vital signs are normal. She is very tender to palption over the left abdomen with positive rebound. White blood count was 20K, amylase and lipase were normal.
Findings

There is diverticulosis of the transverse, descending and sigmoid colon. The distal descending and sigmoid colon has prominent wall thickening with surrounding inflammatory changes of the pericolic fat with adjacent air filled diverticuli. No discrete fluid collections or free air are present.
Differential Diagnosis

1. Diverticulitis. 2. Micro-perforated colon cancer.
Case Diagnosis

Diverticulitis
Diagnosis By

Radiographically. The patient was successfully treated with antibiotics and a follow up study demonstrated marked improvement without evidence of mass.
Treatment & Follow Up

Oral antibiotics are usually required. Liquid or low fiber foods are advised during acute diverticulitis attacks. In severe diverticulitis with high fever and pain, patients are hospitalized and given intravenous antibiotics. Surgery is reserved for those with persistent bowel obstruction or abscess not responding to antibiotics.
Discussion

The patient was admitted to the hospital overnight and was started on intravenous antibiotics. The patient was released the following day on oral antibiotics and underwent a follow-up CT scan to rule out an underlying mass.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Diverticulitis
Disease Discussion

Diverticulitis is the result of perforation of a diverticulum. The perforation is generally localized by the pericolic fat so that free perforation is unusual. The inflammation may evolve into a pericolic abscess or may spread and give rise to a more remote abscess. Fistula formation, most commonly to the bladder, may also complicate diverticulitis. Diverticulitis occurs most frequently in the sigmoid colon, but can occur at other sites (see Film .4). Mild cases of diverticulitis are usually treated medically without carrying out any imaging study for diagnostic confirmation. In more severe cases, a contrast enema may be performed. A water-soluble contrast agent is used instead of barium if there is any evidence of peritonitis. The examination is usually carried out using single contrast technique and careful fluoroscopic observation to identify any contrast extravasation. The most common radiographic finding is an area of eccentric luminal narrowing caused by the pericolic inflammation, together with thickening and distortion of underlying mucosal folds. Adjacent diverticula may also be deformed. Infrequently, as in Film .1, a gas-containing pericolic abscess is shown. The most direct evidence of diverticulitis is local extravasation of contrast material, but this is uncommonly seen. Film .2 illustrates extravasation of contrast into a rounded abscess cavity (arrow) inferior to a segment of sigmoid diverticulitis. Note the grossly thickened folds in the involved segment. Uncommonly, a longitudinal sinus tract forms due to pericolic or intramural dissection parallel to the colon. This gives rise to an appearance of "double-tracking," as indicated in Film .3 by the arrows. Differentiation of diverticulitis from a primary carcinoma, particularly a perforated carcinoma, can sometimes be difficult. Contrast filling of a pericolic abscess, and thickened but intact mucosa, favor the diagnosis of diverticulitis. An example of gross fold thickening and luminal narrowing due to diverticulitis of the hepatic flexure is shown in Film .4. Film .5 demonstrates thickened and distorted mucosal folds in a segment of diverticulitis; carcinoma can be excluded because these folds, though abnormal, have not been destroyed. Metastatic disease to the colon may also mimic diverticulitis. Computed tomography is now frequently utilized in the initial evaluation of severe diverticulitis. The relative roles of CT and contrast enema remain controversial. The earliest change seen on CT is replacement of the normal pericolic fat by hazy soft-tissue densities. In Film .6, these ill-defined pericolic soft-tissue changes (arrow) can be contrasted with the lower density of intra-abdominal fat elsewhere. More severe diverticulitis may give rise to an obvious fluid- or gas-containing pericolic abscess, as indicated by the arrow in Film .7. An additional benefit of CT is that it may be utilized for percutaneous drainage of a peridiverticular abscess, thereby permitting a single surgical resection rather than a two-stage procedure. In Film .8, there are two communicating gas-containing pericolic abscesses (arrows) that were successfully drained using CT guidance (Film .9). In the latter film, the abscess cavities have been opacified with contrast material.
ACR Code

7.-1
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Mnemonic
( This topic was added on 2001-04-04 and last edited on 2004-06-17 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Thymoma
History

63 year old woman with thoracic mass noted on chest radiograph.
Exam

Not available.
Findings

The PA chest radiograph illustrates a rounded opacity superior to the right hilum. The axial CT image demonstrates a soft tissue density in the right anterior mediastinum.
Differential Diagnosis

Differential diagnosis includes: -Thymoma -Lymphoma -Teratoma -Thyroid tumor
Case Diagnosis

Thymoma
Diagnosis By

Surgical resection
Treatment & Follow Up

Surgical resection, chemotheraphy, and radiation therapy are all treatment options.
Discussion

This patient's tumor was resected surgically and adjuvant radiation treatment administered with no evidence of recurrence approximately one year later.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Thymoma
Disease Discussion

The anterior compartment of the mediastinum includes the aorta and its branches, the great veins, thymus, lymphatic tissue, and lung. While many patients are asymptomatic, some patients may have signs or symptoms of mass effect on the surrounding organs, such as cough, chest pain, shortness of breath, or superior vena cava syndrome. They may also have "B" symptoms of fever, night sweats, or weight loss, or they may have symptoms of conditions that are associated with anterior mediastinal tumors, such as myasthenia gravis (thymoma), pure red cell aplasia (thymoma), thyrotoxicosis (thyroid abnormality), or hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid abnormality). The differential diagnosis offered above is often referred to as the 4 "T's" - teratoma, thymoma, thyroid abnormality, or terrible lymphoma. This differential can be much extended, to include cardiovascular masses such as aortic aneurysm, cardiac tumor, paricardial cyst, etc., or metastases of other primary tumors, or tumors of phrenic or vagus nerves, or a number of other lesions. The radiographic appearance of a mediastinal mass can offer some clues to the diagnosis. The radiographs in this case are suggestive of thymoma - the mass is characteristically located between the sternum and heart/great vessels, it is well-circumscribed, and it demonstrates the "sulcus sign." The sulcus sign indicates that the mass is firm, creating a sulcus where the mass meets the sternum or other firm structure, rather than being flattened against the structure and obliterating the sulcus. The well-encapsulated appearance also suggests benign thymoma. Malignancy of thymoma is defined by invasive spread, although thymomas in general are considered slow-growing. Malignant thymomas spread contiguously, and can spread around the pleura and cause multiple pleural masses resembling mesothelioma. Less extensive spread is difficult to rule out. Chest CT may be performed to more sensitively identify invasiveness, but even intraoperatively invasiveness may be difficult to identify. Staging is usually performed with the Masaoka system, but the GETT (French Study Group on Thymic Tumors) is also used. Invasion is the most important prognostic factor with thymoma, with 5-year survival of 70% (50 with local invasion, 75% without invasion), and 10-year survival of 50% (30% with invasion, 60% without invasion). The age of the patient may be used to predict the character of a mass. Thymoma occur most frequently in patients aged 45-50, rarely in patients less than 20, so this patients age of 28 would not have predicted thymoma as being the most likely lesion. Over all age groups, thymoma is the most common primary tumor of the anterior mediastinum, with an incidence of 0.13 in 100,000. In patients aged 20-40, Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and germ cell tumors are most common. These lesions are also most likely to be malignant. Thymoma has a significant association with myasthenia gravis - 40% of patients with a thymoma have myasthenia gravis, and 15% of patients with myesthenia gravis have a thymoma. Thymectomy usually achieves some attenuation of the severity of myesthenia gravis of these patients. 5-15% of patients with thymoma also have pure red cell aplasia, usually occurring in older women - thymectomy resolves this condition in up to 40% of patients. Immunodeficiency resulting from hypogammaglobulinemia and white cell aplasia are much less common, occurring in less than 5% of thymoma patients. Primary treatment for thymoma is surgical resection. Difficulties that may be encountered intraoperatively may include invasion, adhesion of tumor to adjacent structures, or extension of tumor along phrenic nerves which increases the risk of repiratory impairment if these nerves are damaged during dissection. Adjuvant radiation therapy has not been shown to be of benefit after resection of a well-encapsulated, non-invasive tumor. However, adjuvant radiation is often beneficial when used after incomplete resection, after complete resection of invasive tumor, or in unresectable disease. It is sometimes used after total resection in which adhesions were noted. Thymoma is a chemotherapy-sensitive tumor, and chemotherapy may be used in patients with locally invasive or bulky tumors prior to resection. Chemotherapy is also traditionally used for patients with unresectable or metastatic thymoma, or with thymic carcinoma.
ACR Code

67.3154
Location

Chest, Pulmonary (ex. Heart)
Category

Neoplasm, malignant (NOS)
Keywords

thymoma
thymic carcinoma
anterior mediastinum
Reference

Brant, W. E. and Helms, C.A. eds., Fundamentals of Diagnostic Radiology, 2nd ed. 1999. Williams and Wilkins. pp.320-326. Reed, J.C. Chest Radiology - Plain Film Patterns and Differential Diagnoses, 4th ed. 1997. Mosby-Year Book, Inc. pp. 107-124. Salgia, R. "Clinical presentation and management of thymoma." In 2002 UpToDate online, topic last updated 12aug2002.
( This topic was added on 2002-12-12 and last edited on 2004-02-04 )

However, adjuvant radiation is often beneficial when used after incomplete resection, after complete resection of invasive tumor, or in unresectable disease. It is sometimes used after total resection in which adhesions were noted. Thymoma is a chemotherapy-sensitive tumor, and chemotherapy may be used in patients with locally invasive or bulky tumors prior to resection. Chemotherapy is also traditionally used for patients with unresectable or metastatic thymoma, or with thymic carcinoma.
ACR Code
67.3154
Location
Chest, Pulmonary (ex. Heart)
Category
Neoplasm, malignant (NOS)
Keywords
thymoma
thymic carcinoma
anterior mediastinum
Reference
Brant, W. E. and Helms, C.A. eds., Fundamentals of Diagnostic Radiology, 2nd ed. 1999. Williams and Wilkins. pp.320-326. Reed, J.C. Chest Radiology - Plain Film Patterns and Differential Diagnoses, 4th ed. 1997. Mosby-Year Book, Inc. pp. 107-124. Salgia, R. "Clinical presentation and management of thymoma." In 2002 UpToDate online, topic last updated 12aug2002.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Astrocytoma, Low-Grade (WHO 2), Supratentorial
Disease Discussion

Astrocytomas are graded on an ascending scale of agression, from WHO Gr 1 to Gr 4. Circumscribed astrocytoma - like pilocytic and subependymal giant cell - are Gr 1. Non-enhancing low-grade diffuse astrocytoma are Gr2, while anaplastic are Gr 3, and glioblastoma is Gr 4. WHO Gr 2 - most simply called just "astrocytoma" - have a relatively good prognosis. They should not have prominent enhancement. In fact, some literature indicates they should not enhance at all, and they should not have increased perfusion. Sometimes they may have reduced perfusion. They should not show increased metabolism. Prognosis and survival are relatively good. In a review of 179 adult supratentorial low-grade astrocytomas (over 10 years). 80% alive at 5yrs after "total removal". 50% alive at 5yrs after incomplete removal, 45% alive at 5yrs after biopsy. "Among the entire population, the influence of radiotherapy was not obvious: 65% of patients were alive at 5 years without radiotherapy compared to 55% with radiotherapy." Neurosurgery. 1993 Apr;32(4):554-9. PMID: 8474646
ACR Code

1.3
Location

Brain and Neuro
Category

Neoplasm, glial
Keywords

astrocytoma


External Links

www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8474646
( This topic was added on 1999-01-10 and last edited on 2010-12-27 )

patient_details_text:
Demographics
65 y.o. female
Caption

A large heterogeneous hypoattenuating mass within the pancreatic head measuring approximately 7.0 cm x 3.6 cm. There is pancreatic ductal dilatation distal to the mass lesion. The common duct is also dilated at 9mm. No intrahepatic ductal dilatation. The pancreatic mass is encasing the portal vein as well as completely engulfing the splenic vein and superior mesenteric vein. The superior mesenteric vein is encased and the mass is likely invading its lumen. A faint fat plane is seen between the IVC and the pancreatic mass. There is no clear involvement of the superior mesenteric artery with a fat plane surrounding it, however, there is fat stranding within this surrounding fat plane.
Plane

Axial
Modality

CT - GI & IV Contrast
ACR Codes

7.3
