topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma
Disease Discussion

Pancreatic cancer is the fourth leading cause of cancer death in the United States. The prognosis from pancreatic cancer is dismal with a 5 year survival rate of approximately 3%. Adenocarcinoma is the most common non-endocrine neoplasm of the pancreas. A majority of tumors are found in the head of the pancreas (60%) with less in the body (15%) and tail (5%). Approximately 20% are diffuse throughout the pancreas. Early detection while the tumor is resectable remains the only hope for cure for patients, however the vast majority of cases are not resectable at diagnosis. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma’s are typically hpoattenuating when compared to the highly vascular normal pancreas. Secondary signs of a pancreatic lesion are ductal dilatation of the pancreatic and/or common bile ducts the so called “double duct sign,” as well as proximal atrophy of the pancreas. These signs can be helpful when the pancreatic cancer is isoattenuating to the normal pancreatic tissue. CT plays a critical role in surgical planning and determining if a tumor is resectable. The standard surgical procedure is a Whipple procedure which is an excision of the pancreas and second part of the duodenum. If metastases are seen in the liver or peritoneum, the tumor is considered Stage IV and thus unresectable. However, small lesions less than 1cm can be missed by CT. Outside of gross metastatic disease, the most important feature of determining resectability is tumor involvement of the surrounding vasculature to include the superior mesenteric artery, celiac trunk and its branches, portal vein, splenic vein, and superior mesenteric vein. Circumferential narrowing of the SMV or portal vein are considered signs of unresectability. The teardrop SMV is also an indicator of unresectability referring to a focal tethering of a portion of the SMV causing a luminal deformity that causes the lumen to appear like a teardrop. If clear involvement or encasement of the SMA, celiac trunk, hepatic artery, or proximal gastroduodenal artery are present the tumor is unresectable. If a clear fat plan is preserved around the arteries then the lesion is potentially resectable. If the tumor surrounds up to 180degress of the vessel lumen it may be resectable and if it involves greater than 180 degrees of the vessel lumen it is highly likely that the tumor involves the vasculature and is therefore unresectable.
ACR Code

7.3
Location

Gastrointestinal
Category

Neoplasm, non-CNS
Keywords

pancreatic adenocarcinoma


Reference

• Francis, Isaac R. Role of CT in the detection and staging of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Cancer Imaging. 2004; 4(1): 10–14.
• Dimagno, EP; Reber, HA; Tempero, MA. AGA Technical Review on the Epidemiology, Diagnosis, and Treatment of Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma. 1999; 117(6):1464-1484.
• Webb, WR; Brant, WE; Major NM. Fundamentals of Body CT. Third edition. 2006.
• Darren D. D. Brennan, Giulia A. Zamboni, Vassilios D. Raptopoulos, and Jonathan B. Kruskal. Comprehensive Preoperative Assessment of Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma with 64-Section Volumetric CT. RadioGraphics 2007; 27: 1653-1666.
( This topic was added on 2009-09-22 )

case_details_text:
CASE
Angiomyolipoma
History

22 y/o woman presents with acute left sided abdominal pain.
Findings

• Contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates a large enhancing mass in the left kidney. The mass has multiple foci of fat density. Area of increased density within the mass is consistent with hemorrhage.
• Catheter angiogram shows large mass feed by interlobar artery with prominent neovascularity and delayed washout.
• Post-embolization images show absent flow to the mass.
Differential Diagnosis

• Angiomyolipoma
• Renal cell carcinoma surrounding renal sinus fat
Case Diagnosis

Angiomyolipoma
Diagnosis By

Imaging
Treatment & Follow Up

Due to the size of the mass and the presentation with acute hemorrhage, treatment was indicated. The patient underwent selective catheter based embolization of the lesion.
Discussion

This woman was known to have Tuberous Sclerosis (TS). AML occurs in a majority of TS patients, though often small and uncomplicated. Symptoms rarely occur in patients with AMLs less than 4cm in size. Tumors greater than 4cm are symptomatic 80-90% of the time and 50-60% bleed spontaneously. Embolization of angiomyolipomas is an effective, minimally invasive treatment. The technical success rate is near 100%. Recurrence (increase in size >2cm on follow-up imaging and/or recurrent symptoms requiring repeat embolization) is rare in sporadic AMLs. The recurrence rate is higher in patients with TS and lifelong imaging is recommended. Kothary N, Soulen MC, Clark TW, et al. Renal Angiomyolipoma: Long-term Results after Arterial Embolization. J Vasc Interv Radiol. 2005; 16:45-50.

topic_text:
VIEW TOPIC IMAGES
TOPIC
Angiomyolipoma
Disease Discussion

An angiomyolipoma (AML) is a hamartomatous lesion containing fat, smooth muscle, and blood vessels. AMLs are felt to represent a subset of familial neoplasms derived from perivascular epithelioid cells. Most are asymptomatic, and one source (Eble) reports an incidence of 13 per 10,000 adults. The typical imaging finding is fat in a renal lesion, thought by many to be virtually diagnostic of AML. Rarely, however, renal cell cancers and oncocytomas can also contain fat. Hence, these lesions should also be considered in the differential. Small lesions generally receive no treatment, with resection or embolization being reserved for larger or symptomatic lesions. The primary complication associated with this lesion is spontaneous hemorrhage. Other possible complications include extension into the inferior vena cava and spread to local lymph nodes without progression to malignancy. It should be noted, however, that one subtype of AML, the epithelioid angiomyolipoma, does have malignant potential. AMLs, in particular bilateral AMLs, are associated with tuberous sclerosis. In tuberous sclerosis, concurrent cysts and, occasionally, renal cell carcinoma may be present. Hormones may stimulate the growth of these lesions as evidenced by the observations that (1) they are generally diagnosed only after puberty in patients with tuberous sclerosis, (2) large AMLs are more common in women than in men, and (3) AMLs sometimes demonstrate significant growth during pregnancy.
ACR Code

8.3
Location

Genitourinary
Category

Neoplasm, benign
Keywords

Renal neoplasm
Angiomyolipoma
tuberous sclerosis
Reference

1. Eble JN. Angiomyolipoma of kidney. Abstract, Semin Diagn Pathol 1998 Feb;15(1):21-40.
( This topic was added on 2001-10-15 and last edited on 2001-10-16 )
